This satire contains a dialogue between Horace and Treba- tius, an eminent counsellor and a distinguished scholar. The poet asks the advice of Trebatius, who counsels him to give up the writing of satires, as calculated to render him odious ς and to celebrate the achievements of Augustus. Horace refuses to follow his advice, saying that he was not qualified for so high asubject3 but that he must write something, and as he liked satire, and as no one had any right to be displeased with him sor satirizing vices, if he lived correctly himself, he should go on writing in this way.
